name: Kauffman–Harary conjecture
rephrased: Every non-trivial alternating link has exactly one non-orientable spanning surface (up to non-isotopy).
implication_form: If a link is non-trivial and alternating, then it has exactly one non-orientaneous spanning surface (up to non-isotopy).
explained: The Kauffman–Harary conjecture, proposed by Louis Kauffman and Frank Harary, states that every non-trivial spatial graph (a graph embedded in 3-dimensional space) is prime. A spatial graph is considered prime if it cannot be decomposed non-trivially. The conjecture specifically addresses prime decomposition with respect to the operation of taking a connected sum of spatial graphs. Two spatial graphs are said to be connected along a graph H if they share an embedding of H and their embeddings do not intersect outside of H. The connected sum is formed by removing a small neighborhood of H from both graphs and gluing them together along the boundary torus or sphere associated with H. A spatial graph is prime if it cannot be expressed as a non-trivial connected sum of two spatial graphs. The conjecture claims that all non-trivial spatial graphs are prime, meaning they cannot be broken down into simpler components via this connected sum operation.
related_conjectures: Kneser conjecture (deals with graph coloring, but related in spirit to decomposition properties)
Additive basis conjectures (related to decomposition principles in other areas)
